column1: The city was named for the nearby Wenatchi Indian tribe. The name is a Sahaptin word that means "river which comes [or whose source is] from canyons" or "robe of the rainbow". Awenatchela means "people at the source [of a river]". The city of Wenatchee shares its name with the Wenatchee River
column2: Lake Wenatchee and the Wenatchee National Forest.

column1: Wenatchee is referred to as the "Apple Capital of the World" due to the valley's many orchards. The city is also sometimes referred to as the "Buckle of the Power Belt of the Great Northwest".  The "Power Belt of the Great Northwest" is a metaphor for the series of hydroelectric dams on the Columbia River.  Rock Island Dam is located nearest to the middle of this "belt"
column2: and so was labeled the "Buckle". This saying is printed at the top of every issue of Wenatchee's newspaper
column3: the Wenatchee World
column4: but is no longer in common use elsewhere.

column1: Archeological digs in nearby East Wenatchee have uncovered Clovis stone and bone tools dating back more than 11
column3: indicating that people migrating during the last Ice Age spent time in the Wenatchee area. The Columbia River and nearby mountains and sagebrush steppes provided an ample supply of food. Clovis points are on display at the Wenatchee Valley Museum & Cultural Center and research findings are available through the Wenatchee World.

column1: Several indigenous villages existed in the area prior to and during Anglo American exploration. The village Nikwikwi'estku was a fishing and gathering camp located in present-day downtown Wenatchee. In 1811
column2: North West Company surveyor David Thompson encountered a group of Native American horsemen at Wenatchee and was invited into a village with huts
column3: the largest measuring 209 feet long. Fur traders document friendly relations through the mid 19th century
column4: even during the smallpox epidemic of 1817 and food shortages in 1841.During the Yakima War in 1856
column5: US Army Colonel Wright intervened on a possible alliance between Yakama and Wenatchi tribes by removing the Wenatchi to Kittitas. The resulting march was estimated to include 1
column6: 000 horses and extend five miles long. A contingent stayed behind to fish at Wenatchapam Fishery in preparation for winter.In 1863

column1: The Great Northern Railway completed its railroad line between St. Paul
column3: and Seattle in 1893. Its route through the Wenatchee Valley was significant to the development of this region. The railroad not only provided passenger travel to and from Wenatchee
column4: but it provided for freight service for shipments of wheat
column5: apples
column6: and other products to out-of-state markets.

column3: the Wenatchee free speech fight occurred when members of the Industrial Workers of the World (IWW) were arrested for speaking in the street in front of the local hall of the Socialist Party of America. The town had freed imprisoned IWW members by June; however
column4: tensions resumed in September 1911 when police raided a house rented by six IWW men and arrested twenty-five migrant workers found carrying IWW literature. Again
column5: the men were all quickly released.In 1922
column6: a Ku Klux Klan chapter of nearly 100 men demanded that black residents leave on threat of violence. By 1923 they hosted meetings of up to 400 members and burned a large cross above Fancher airfield in East Wenatchee. The Wenatchee chapter hosted the 1926 state Klan convention and marched in the Apple Blossom Parade. In the wave of anti-Filipino sentiment
column7: Filipino immigrant workers were targeted by violence and deportation through the late 1920s.

column3: Clyde Pangborn and his copilot Hugh Herndon landed their airplane
column4: named the Miss Veedol

column6: and thus became the first aviators to fly nonstop across the Pacific Ocean. The 41-hour flight from Sabishiro Beach
column10: won them the Harmon Trophy for the greatest achievement in flight of 1931. Miss Veedol's propeller is on display at the Wenatchee Valley Museum & Cultural Center.

column1: Wenatchee is located at the confluence of the Wenatchee and Columbia rivers in the Columbia Basin

column1: The Wenatchee Valley and the surrounding areas provide an abundance of sports and recreational activities for any season. There are several facilities including the WRAC tennis club
column3: an ice arena

column5: a 9-hole disc golf course

column7: fish and hunt for both birds and larger game. Boating and water recreation are also quite common. Many kayak
column8: windsurf and water-ski on the Columbia. Whitewater rafting and inner-tubing is frequent on the Wenatchee River. In the winter
column9: the mountains near Wenatchee provide great snowmobiling
column11: as well as skiing and snowboarding at Mission Ridge (30 minutes drive) and Stevens Pass (1 hour and a half drive).  Nordic skiing is available at the Stevens Pass Nordic Center
column13: and the Methow Valley (1 hour and 45 minute drive).

column1: The city also offers a large system of parks and paved trails known as the Apple Capital Recreation Loop Trail. The 10-mile (16 km) loop along both banks of the Columbia River is used by cyclists
column3: joggers
column4: and skaters. A project to extend the eastern segment of the trail 5 miles (8.0 km) north to Lincoln Rock State Park was completed on July 9
column5: 2015. An additional 3.2-mile (5.1 km) extension on the east side runs south to Kirby Billingsley Hydro Park. A short extension slated for completion in Fall 2017 is planned from the west end of the Odabashian bridge to the corner of Easy Street and the highway.  In the winter
column6: cross-country skiers and snowshoers also use the trail. The trail connects in the south at the historic Columbia River Bridge
column7: also known as the pipeline bridge
column8: and in the north at the Richard Odabashian Bridge.  It passes through Wenatchee Confluence State Park. Much of the hillside areas surrounding the city of Wenatchee have been purchased by or have their rights held by the Chelan-Douglas Land Trust which protects them as a natural resource and as a site for hiking in the foothills.  The foothills trail system along the western edge of Wenatchee provides numerous short trails of varying difficulty for walking

column4: one fire department (Chelan County Fire District No. 1)

column1: Wenatchee is in the major railroad line of the BNSF Railway (formerly Great Northern Railway) to Seattle. Wenatchee was once the eastern terminus of the Great Northern electric-driven train service (1928/1929–1956) on its  New Cascade Tunnel route via the Chumstick Valley
column2: which went all the way to Skykomish. There
column3: steam locomotives or diesel locomotives replaced electric locomotives along this route
column4: as well as having a maintenance base for the electric locomotives. Today
column5: Amtrak's Empire Builder passenger train serves Wenatchee at Columbia Station.
